introduction.p: For Problems 13, apply the zero-factor principle to find the solutions.

For Problems 45,
Verify that the factored form for each expression is correct.
Use the factored form to find the solutions of the original equation.
Check algebraically that your answers to part (b) actually are solutions of the original equation.
For Problems 68, find the largest common factor for the monomials.
For Problems 912, fill in the missing algebraic expressions.
For Problems 1315, factor out the largest common factor.
For Problems 1618, factor the right side of the formula.

ol.label: a

li.p: Complete the table of values for the equation y=-x^2+6x, then graph the equation on the grid.

ol.li: Use your graph to find the solutions of the equation -x^2+6x=5.
Verify algebraically that your answers to part (a) are really solutions.
Use your graph to find the solutions of the equation -x^2+6x=0.
Verify algebraically that your answers to part (d) are really solutions.
Compute the product -x(x+6). What do you get?
What is the value of the expression -x(x+6) when x=0? When x=6?

answer.p: b. x=1, or x=5 ~~~ d. x=0, or x=6

ol.label: a

li.p: Complete the table of values for the equation y=x^2+2x-8, then graph the equation on the grid.

ol.li: Use your graph to find the solutions of the equation x^2+2x-8=7.
Verify algebraically that your answers to part (a) are really solutions.
Use your graph to find the solutions of the equation x^2+2x-8=0.
Verify algebraically that your answers to part (d) are really solutions.
Compute the product (x+4)(x-2). What do you get?
What is the value of the expression (x+4)(x-2) when x=-4? When x=2?

introduction.p: For Problems 3032, find the x-intercepts of the graph of the equation.
For Problems 3334, graph all three equations on the same grid. What do you observe?
For Problems 3536, \alert{\text{find the mistake}} in the steps for solution, then write a correct solution.
